title: Which profession attracts the worst kinds of people?

stories.fullText: I‚Äôm a casino dealer. People losing money brings out the worst qualities in them. Especially when I deal high limit games. Plus the pit boss/supervisors won‚Äôt throw a person out who is literally spending thousands. Doesn‚Äôt matter what they do or say. The casino doesn‚Äôt want to lose those kinds of patrons. They‚Äôre catered to. They can be so awful to the dealers. The job has made me look at humanity in a completely different light lol.   Pro relationship tip: Bring a date to the casino and see how they treat the dealer if they‚Äôre losing. You‚Äôll see what kind of person they really are. I have about 10 years of experience in the industry.

stories.fullText: Law enforcement - double-edged sword, because it attracts the best and the worst. The best in people who want to help, protect, and do good. The WORST in people who want to exact authority over people. Power-hungry assholes who are insecure and have short fuses and low tolerance for defiance. If you can't handle someone defying you without losing your s  you shouldn't be a cop.  Edit: spelling

stories.fullText: Substance abuse mental health professionals seem to fall into one of the following categories: a) wonderful, angelic and highly competent souls who truly want to help drug addicts/alcoholics (they're maybe 20% of the counselors, optimistically); b) burnt-out incompetent/lazy/don't-care types (another 60%); or c) absolute personality-disordered, narcissistic/ Machiavellian sadistic types who really get off on the enormous power/control they have over the lives and fates of the people under their care (maybe another 20%). YMMV. The last group can do a LOT of damage.

stories.fullText: Sales.  I swear to God, salesmen have an uncanny knack for justifying immoral decisions.  Maybe it's because it's so frequently paid in piece rate so they will quite literally do/say anything to get the sale, even if it's 100% false, but wOw salesmen seem like they would sell their mom to the devil for a quarter if given the opportunity.

stories.fullText: Academia.  Intelligent people in very niche areas, with no consideration for the real world and social interaction, whilst simultaneously being told they are the best in the world at certain specific subject areas (which is true, but just not as many people care as academics think they do). You end up with an unnecessarily toxic environment of people trying to intellectually one up each other and throw anyone off the ladder on their way up.  It's a cruel, nasty, petty, and poisonous environment.

stories.fullText: Volunteer  supervisor  type positions. In non-profit, we sometimes have to rely on volunteers for jobs which would normally be paid positions in corporate. The people who want jobs with power over other people and are willing to do it for free are often some of the nastiest, abusive people you'll ever meet. You're not going to find a normal person for it. You just have to assess if they'll be tolerable or not

stories.fullText: Not so much profession but I‚Äôm finding schools to be really weird.  I‚Äôve never worked in a school before but quickly finding it‚Äôs like they are their own countries.   Beaches of privacy everywhere, teachers using mobile phones in class to text, admin doing things that are wayyyy behind their pay grade I could go on and on.  What I‚Äôve found is there is a real lack of connectedness among her people who aren‚Äôt teachers.  Teachers stick together and then there‚Äôs everyone else, doesn‚Äôt matter what our role is social work, psychologist, wellbeing officer, admin , there just isn‚Äôt a team feeling.  It can be a toxic environment.
